The plan implemented by the inpatient pharmacy department was prepared while incorporating information and recommendations from leading pharmacy organizations, ministry of health, institute's experience in battling another similar coronavirus (the Middle East respiratory syndrome-coronavirus) previously, and updated scientific research. The key focus areas include development of an institutionalized COVID-19 protocol, measures to improve infection control when handling and dispensing medications, modified staffing plan, system changes in peri-operative areas, keeping pharmacy professionals updated about new and scientific researches, increased utilization of automation, clinical interventions by pharmacist ensuring appropriate utilization of medications while monitoring for drug-drug interactions, adverse drug event prevention, and preparing for handling drug shortages. body_text.text: The coronavirus disease 2019 is an ongoing pandemic having caused a major health care crises across the globe.Pharmacy professionals are considered vital in preparation for optimal response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Therefore, in response to the estimated potential impact of COVID-19 on Johns Hopkins Aramco Healthcare (joint venture between Saudi Aramco and Johns Hopkins Medicine International), several initiatives were taken by the hospital's inpatient pharmacy department with focus on infection control, staffing, meeting clinical operational challenges, ethics, increased utilization of automation, and maintenance of employee wellness to prepare for this challenge. The plan implemented by the inpatient pharmacy department was prepared while incorporating information and recommendations from leading pharmacy organizations, ministry of health, institute's experience in battling another similar coronavirus (the Middle East respiratory syndrome-coronavirus) previously, and updated scientific research. The key focus areas include development of an institutionalized COVID-19 protocol, measures to improve infection control when handling and dispensing medications, modified staffing plan, system changes in peri-operative areas, keeping pharmacy professionals updated about new and scientific researches, increased utilization of automation, clinical interventions by pharmacist ensuring appropriate utilization of medications while monitoring for drug-drug interactions, adverse drug event prevention, and preparing for handling drug shortages. By implementing a robust plan, pharmacy professionals continue to show that they are an integral member of inter-professional health care teams.

Clinical Interventions: A variety of valuable clinical interventions were conducted by inpatient pharmacists. These 35 include:

• Therapeutic drug monitoring for hydroxychloroquine and lopinavir/ritonavir has been enacted to avoid 37 inappropriate prescribing, and prevent adverse drug events. QT-interval was monitored for patients prescribed 38 hydroxychloroquine by the clinical pharmacist. 5
• The pharmacy issued guidance on the dispensing of hydroxychloroquine upon discharge for the treatment of 40 COVID-19.
• Transition from nebulizers to hand-held inhalers for patients requiring inhaled therapy when feasible and safe. 6
• Review of electronic best practice advisory for hydroxychloroquine such as monitoring parameters for baseline 43 and follow up ECG incorporated into the computerized physician order entry system.
• Medication adjustment for patients with renal insufficiency being made per institutional policy.
• Computerized physician order entry system generated report utilized to review liquid medication preparations, and 51 their rationale for use to avoid wastage.

Safety measures for infection control: Several safety measures have been taken to protect both our pharmacy staff 54 and our patients using the interim guidance from governmental and professional pharmacy organizations. Some of the 55 key best practices adopted included: minimum distance of 1.5meters. 9
• Adding floor markings on the ground to section areas of the pharmacy that patients can stand in while waiting or 64 being helped.
• Nursing unit inspections being done on regular basis with special emphasis on neuromuscular blockers and 66 emergency medication kits such as 'rapid sequence intubation'kits.
• Guidance provided for pharmacists in emergency services pharmacy on socially-distanced methods of patient 68 counseling and prescription handling. 9
• Enable independent double check for high alert medications to be conducted at the automated drug dispensing 70 system in isolation wards instead of patient bedside.
• Based on organizational medication administration guideline consolidate dispensing times -e.g., every 12 hours 72 to twice daily, eliminate outlier medication administration times.
• For empty narcotic vials in operating rooms and isolated floor automated drug dispensing system, users to ensure 74 wearing gloves and mask before handling and sealing in cartons. 10 75 76

Staffing plan: A temporary department-wide staffing plan has been implemented to adjust to the current situation. The 77 staffing was modified based on both the restrictions imposed by the government and the advice from ministry of health.

System changes in Peri-Operative areas: Automated drug dispensing systems were removed from two operating 99 rooms, and cardiac catheterization (cath) labs were reserved to manage COVID-19 patients to avoid contamination.

Instead, they were supplied isolation kits with medications. In the event, the hospital reaches full capacity for COVID-19 101 patients, two new "clean areas" in post anesthesia care unit and outpatient procedure area have been created. Automated 102 drug dispensing system has been already mapped to serve these new areas.

Communication:The pharmacy department is ensuring that relevant information about inpatient pharmacy updates is 105 communicated to the employees, colleagues from other departments as well as our valued patients. Pharmacy employees 106 received emails about preparedness, schedule changes, workplace mitigation strategies, and Johns Hopkins Aramco 107 healthcare and ministry of health COVID-19 updates. Also, webinars and resources are available to seek more 108 information.Given rapidly evolving data on COVID-19, a weekly update series prepared by an inpatient pharmacist is 109 being shared as internal circular to increase awareness amongst staff about recent scientific and research updates.
85% of the medication dispensing for the majority of patient areas are fulfilled by the automated drug dispensing system.

Following the announcement from the organization about the pandemic, a decision was made to maximize the capacity of 127 automated drug dispensing systems, especially for the isolation areas and intensive care units. A periodic review of cart-128 fill medications was scheduled with pharmacy automation team. This strategy helped us to minimize the visit to those 129 areas where isolation precautions are strictly enforced.

Cart-fill medications are being perpetually reviewed, utilizing system-generated reports. Based on the findings of the 131 report, more medications were added to the automated drug dispensing system and par levels (days of stock) were 132 increased to reduce the frequency of restocking and thereby reduce traffic to the central pharmacy. 9 In the central 133 pharmacy, a container of the appropriate cleaning disinfectant was placed nearby to allow those accessing the automated 134 drug dispensing system to disinfect common touch points. 15

The system in place already does not allow medications removed from the automated drug dispensing system to be 136 returned to the specific bin or pocket from which they were removed. This was reinforced to minimize the risk of errors 137 and cross-contamination. A designated return bin for medication is used for returning un-administered medications to the 138 pharmacy, as long as they have not entered an isolation patient's room.

Also, as part of allied health care professional upscaling program, some of the pharmacy staff has been 86 cross-trained to serve other patient care areas. 11 The administration also tried to look for schedule solutions, keeping 87 mental health of their staff in mind. 12, 13 Pharmacists and pharmacy technicians are reminded of the importance of taking 88 care of their own wellbeing and that of those they manage. 12, 13 All pharmacy staff was informed of launch of Johns 89 Hopkins Aramco healthcare staff emotional and domestic abuse support help line. 13 90 91 92 Supporting Quarantine areas: In response to COVID-19, a number of quarantine facilities were established. To 93 support these facilities a standardized list of commonly used medications including antipyretics and analgesics was made 94 following a discussion with primary care team and the nurse practitioners. The list has been uploaded to hospital's 95 material management system. This enables front line nursing staff to request the medications online for the guests in96 quarantine facilities.
